title: Welcome to rFishStatus
text:
This document serves as a tutorial for the R package rFishStatus and outlines its design and development following the Design Science Research Methodology (DSRM).
rFishStatus aims to address the challenge of nomenclature inconsistencies in fish occurrence databases. The package was initially developed for the Paraná State region in Brazil, with the flexibility to be adapted for other geographical areas given appropriate input data.

title: Welcome to rFishStatus
Welcome to rFishStatus
text:
How to Cite
If you use rFishStatus in your work, please cite it as follows:

Fabrin, T.M.C., et al. (2024). rFishStatus: An R package for assisting in the correction of nomenclature conflicts in fish occurrence data. GitHub repository: https://github.com/thomazfabrin/rFishStatus

title: Welcome to rFishStatus
text:
Document Structure (DSRM)
This tutorial/report follows the Design Science Research Methodology (DSRM) stages:

Problem Identification and Motivation
Definition of the Objectives for a Solution
Design and Development of the Artifact (rFishStatus)
Demonstration (Usage Tutorial)
Evaluation
Communication and Conclusion

title: rFishStatus
text:
Several scientific investigations rely on accurate species identification and distribution data to draw conclusions across a wide range of research topics. This includes descriptive taxonomic and/or molecular identification studies as well as more complex modeling of species distribution over time to formulate assumptions. In any case, both approaches require robust and accurate species identification as a prerequisite. However, to ensure the reliability of species databases, innovative tools capable of addressing these challenges are needed. From a taxonomic perspective, challenges also persist regarding the incorporation of newly discovered taxa into these databases, alongside concerns about the reliability of the information contained therein, particularly considering that these resources are mainly accessed by non-taxonomist end-users (Ebach, Valdecasas, and Wheeler 2011). This is an important aspect since several commonly used databases are not synchronous regarding species status updates.
The primary route for accessing taxonomic information relies on public databases, accessible to both taxonomists and non-taxonomists. These databases are hosted on web platforms like FishBase and Eschmeyer’s Catalog of Fishes. Additionally, there are specific packages designed to curate and construct local species databases. However, a challenge arises in validating species nomenclature from databases that do not synchronously update with species status changes, especially for occurrence entries made by non-taxonomist users without cross-verification. To mitigate errors in data entry into these databases, several potential solutions have emerged. These solutions include the adoption of molecular identification techniques such as DNA barcoding, which facilitates species identification (DeSalle and Goldstein 2019), and the expansion of taxonomic expertise through the training of more taxonomists. Taxonomists play a crucial role in reviewing and validating species identification and nomenclature before new data are added to these databases (Ebach, Valdecasas, and Wheeler 2011).
The correct identification and classification of organisms present multiple challenges, and their impact varies depending on the scientific, social, and political context. Poor taxonomic hypotheses, for instance, can result in misguided conservation priorities. The differentiation and discovery of species, while distinct terms, rely heavily on the foundation of trustworthy pre-existing information, which is predominantly accessed through these databases. Despite the partial automation of certain processes, taxonomic scrutiny remains important, particularly for taxonomic groups that remain incompletely understood. Consequently, the development of tools aimed at rectifying and validating data within cyber-infrastructures used for disseminating taxonomic information to end-users is important (De Carvalho et al. 2005, 2007). This is especially true given that the majority of end-users lack taxonomic expertise and often need to integrate data from various databases into a unique dataset for posterior analysis.
In light of this, the demand for automation is increasing in the era of big data. Processing such data needs highly specialized tools that can be customized by end-users to align with their requirements. These tools have the potential to not only flag incorrect species status but also propose possible corrections, thereby contributing to the generation of more reliable data. The main challenge is taxonomic harmonization, the process of matching species names with those from a reference database, if not the main one, and checking their status. To avoid reinventing the wheel, the primary step is combining existing tools into a unified solution that facilitates a “clean” and streamlined workflow for harmonizing taxonomic information, making it accessible for different types of research. This necessitates the fusion of web knowledge, biological background, and programming development skills, enabling the processing and organization of online data to create an accessible resource (Grenié et al. 2023).
Here, we introduce an R package designed for managing fish nomenclature data. Our goal was to process the data to generate a species list as curated and updated as possible. Additionally, we provide functions to update the status and nomenclature of species in occurrence datasets from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF), and to interpret and compare species input data. To test rFishStatus, we used the Design Science Research Methodology (DSRM), following specific guidelines (Lacerda et al. 2013; Hevner and Chatterjee 2010; Peffers et al. 2007). The primary objective was to address the challenges associated with curating input lists of fish species, either sourced from users or occurrence datasets. The usage of the package is demonstrated across various scenarios.

title: 1. Problem Identification and Motivation
text:
Motivation for rFishStatus
[Explain why a dedicated R package is needed and the value it provides. E.g., to offer a semi-automated, reproducible, and adaptable workflow for standardizing fish names.]

title: rFishStatus
text:
The development of the rFishStatus R package is driven by the need to address critical challenges in managing and utilizing fish occurrence data. The primary objectives of this artifact are:

To improve data curation and accuracy:

Provide tools to process reference data.
Facilitate the updating of species status and nomenclature in existing occurrence datasets.

To streamline taxonomic harmonization:

Offer functions to address the taxonomic harmonization by matching species names from input lists or occurrence datasets against a reference database and verifying their current status.
Combine existing tools and knowledge into a unified solution that facilitates a streamlined workflow for harmonizing taxonomic information.

To support data validation and error reduction by end-users:

Develop functionalities that flag incorrect or outdated species status, and also propose possible corrections.
Enable users to interpret and compare species input data effectively.
Provide tools that can be customized by end-users to align with their specific requirements.

The development of the rFishStatus R package is driven by the need to address critical challenges in managing and utilizing fish occurrence data. The primary objectives of this artifact are:

To improve data curation and accuracy:

Provide tools to process reference data.
Facilitate the updating of species status and nomenclature in existing occurrence datasets.

To streamline taxonomic harmonization:

Offer functions to address the taxonomic harmonization by matching species names from input lists or occurrence datasets against a reference database and verifying their current status.
Combine existing tools and knowledge into a unified solution that facilitates a streamlined workflow for harmonizing taxonomic information.

To support data validation and error reduction by end-users:

Develop functionalities that flag incorrect or outdated species status, and also propose possible corrections.
Enable users to interpret and compare species input data effectively.
Provide tools that can be customized by end-users to align with their specific requirements.

title: rFishStatus
text:
rFishStatus is a package designed to help you assess the status and nomenclature of fish species in input lists or occurrence datasets (currently only GBIF is supported). This tutorial will guide you through the process of using the package effectively.


To use the package, you need to prepare your data in a specific format following the rFishStatus template. To see an example of it you can run the following code:


Code
library(rFishStatus)
library(dplyr)

# Let's check the template reference
glimpse(data_template_ref)


Rows: 2,363
Columns: 15
$ scientific_name_complete    <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ scientific_name             <chr> "Geophagus abalios", "Limnochromis abeelei…
$ scientific_name_author      <chr> "López-Fernández  & Taphorn  2004", "Poll …
$ scientific_name_genus       <chr> "Geophagus", "Limnochromis", "Sparus", "He…
$ scientific_name_family      <chr> "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae", "Ci…
$ scientific_name_status      <chr> "Valid", "Synonym", "Uncertain", "Synonym"…
$ species_valid_name_complete <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ species_valid_as_complete   <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ species_valid_as_short      <chr> "Geophagus abalios", "Greenwoodochromis ab…
$ species_valid_name_genus    <chr> "Geophagus", "Greenwoodochromis", NA, "Aus…
$ species_valid_name_author   <chr> "López-Fernández & Taphorn 2004", "(Poll 1…
$ species_valid_name_year     <chr> "2004", "1949", NA, "1870", "2015", "1967"…
$ scientific_name_synonym_of  <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ all_valid_species_complete  <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ scientific_name_habitat     <chr> "freshwater", "freshwater", "freshwater", …


All functions in rFishStatuswill use this template as a reference. For more details please refer to the data template documentation.
This reference dataset will then be used to construct a reference list of fish species, which will be used to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in your input list. This is basically the List Curation Workflow shown in Design & Development section.



The first step in using rFishStatus is to create a reference species list from the data template. This list will be used to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in your input list. You can create the reference species list by running the following code:


Code
library(rFishStatus)

reference_spp_list <- rfs_get_species_list(
    # Here we use the data template reference
    # But you can use your own dataset
    df = data_template_ref
)





Sample of reference species list from the rFishStatus template













scientific_name
status
scientific_name_family
genus
species
valid_scientific_name
sci_name_year
sci_name_authors
valid_sci_name_habitat

Chocoheros microlepis (Dahl 1960)
Valid
Cichlidae
Chocoheros
Chocoheros microlepis
Chocoheros microlepis (Dahl 1960)
1960
Dahl
freshwater


Melanochromis brevis Trewavas 1935
Synonym
Cichlidae
Melanochromis
Melanochromis brevis
Pseudotropheus brevis (Trewavas 1935)
1935
Trewavas
freshwater


Neolamprologus splendens (Brichard 1989)
Valid
Cichlidae
Neolamprologus
Neolamprologus splendens
Neolamprologus splendens (Brichard 1989)
1989
Brichard
freshwater


Oreochromis aureus (Steindachner 1864)
Valid
Cichlidae
Oreochromis
Oreochromis aureus
Oreochromis aureus (Steindachner 1864)
1864
Steindachner
freshwater, brackish





Once you obtain the reference list, you can load your input dataset to be assessed. This dataset should be a dataframe, with a column named species. For further details on the input dataset format, please refer to the rfs_update_list().


Let’s create a sample input list and compare it with the reference species list using rfs_update_list().


Code
# Create a sample input list
input_list <- data.frame(
    species = c(
        "Crenicichla britskii",
        "Cicha kelberi",
        "Geophagus brasiliensis"
    )
)

# Check the input list against the reference species list
result <- rfs_update_list(
    input_list = input_list,
    reference_list = reference_spp_list
)





Sample of the result of rfs_update_list()












query_species
scientific_name
status
genus
valid_scientific_name
valid_sci_name_habitat
species
family




Cicha kelberi
Cichla kelberi Kullander & Ferreira 2006
Valid (fuzzy matching) - Please check the status and the spelling of your query
Cichla
Cichla kelberi Kullander & Ferreira 2006
freshwater
Cichla kelberi
Cichlidae


Crenicichla britskii
Crenicichla britskii Kullander 1982
Synonym
Crenicichla
Saxatilia britskii (Kullander 1982)
freshwater
Saxatilia britskii
Cichlidae


Geophagus brasiliensis
Geophagus brasiliensis (Quoy & Gaimard 1824) or Geophagus brasiliensis Kner 1865
Valid
Geophagus or Geophagus
Geophagus brasiliensis (Quoy & Gaimard 1824)
freshwater, brackish
Geophagus brasiliensis
Cichlidae





A typo was added to the input list (Cicha kelberi) to demonstrate how rfs_update_list() can identify it.




The second workflow is the Occurrence Data Workflow, which is used to assess the status and nomenclature of fish species in occurrence datasets (so far this is specificaly tailored to work with GBIF data, so you will need GBIF credentials that can be obtained here). This workflow runs the previous workflow internally, but it also includes additional steps to obtain occurrence data automatically from GBIF. First you need to download the occurrence data from GBIF using rfs_download_occ_data(). This function will download the occurrence data automatically by interacting with the rgbif package. Let’s download all Crenicichla occurrence for the state of Paraná, Brazil, and save it in data/occ_data:


Code
# Download occurrence data from GBIF
# Obs. You don't need to assign the result to a variable, since it will execute and 
# save the data in the folder passed as an argument

dotenv::load_dot_env()

rfs_download_occ_data(
    gbif_user = Sys.getenv("GBIF_USER"),
    gbif_pwd = Sys.getenv("GBIF_PWD"),
    gbif_email = Sys.getenv("GBIF_EMAIL"),
    folder_name = "data/occ_data",
    country = "Brazil",
    state = "Paraná",
    reverse_polygon = TRUE,
    taxonkey = 2370916, # Taxonkey for Crenicichla
)


After downloading the data let’s check it in the folder data/occ_data:


Code
# Check the downloaded data
occ_data <- list.files("data/occ_data", full.names = TRUE) |>
    readr::read_delim()

dplyr::glimpse(occ_data)


Rows: 2,134
Columns: 50
$ gbifID                           <dbl> 666715934, 666712781, 666594313, 6665…
$ datasetKey                       <chr> "afc30a94-6107-488a-b9c0-ba9c4fa68b7c…
$ occurrenceID                     <chr> "2929e2b8-040f-42bd-897c-e37aec4bf107…
$ kingdom                          <chr> "Animalia", "Animalia", "Animalia", "…
$ phylum                           <chr> "Chordata", "Chordata", "Chordata", "…
$ class                            <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ order                            <chr> "Perciformes", "Perciformes", "Percif…
$ family                           <chr> "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae"…
$ genus                            <chr> "Crenicichla", "Crenicichla", "Crenic…
$ species                          <chr> "Crenicichla tingui", "Crenicichla ig…
$ infraspecificEpithet             <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ taxonRank                        <chr> "SPECIES", "SPECIES", "SPECIES", "SPE…
$ scientificName                   <chr> "Crenicichla tingui Kullander & Lucen…
$ verbatimScientificName           <chr> "Crenicichla tingui", "Crenicichla ig…
$ verbatimScientificNameAuthorship <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ countryCode                      <chr> "BR", "BR", "BR", "BR", "BR", "BR", "…

$ stateProvince                    <chr> "Paraná", NA, NA, NA, "Paraná", "Para…
$ occurrenceStatus                 <chr> "PRESENT", "PRESENT", "PRESENT", "PRE…
$ individualCount                  <dbl> 5, 1, 1, 3, 2, 138, 16, 1, 2, 2, 8, 1…
$ publishingOrgKey                 <chr> "7b8aff00-a9f8-11d8-944b-b8a03c50a862…
$ decimalLatitude                  <dbl> -25.47570, -26.23022, -26.23022, -26.…
$ decimalLongitude                 <dbl> -48.83287, -51.07758, -51.07758, -51.…
$ coordinateUncertaintyInMeters    <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ coordinatePrecision              <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ elevation                        <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ elevationAccuracy                <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ depth                            <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ depthAccuracy                    <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ eventDate                        <chr> "1909-01-04", "1908", "1908", "1908",…
$ day                              <dbl> 4, NA, NA, NA, 6, 7, 6, 13, 11, 10, 1…
$ month                            <dbl> 1, NA, NA, NA, 12, 12, 12, 10, 9, 11,…
$ year                             <dbl> 1909, 1908, 1908, 1908, 1998, 1998, 1…
$ taxonKey                         <dbl> 2370990, 2370942, 2370942, 2370942, 2…
$ speciesKey                       <dbl> 2370990, 2370942, 2370942, 2370942, 2…
$ basisOfRecord                    <chr> "PRESERVED_SPECIMEN", "PRESERVED_SPEC…
$ institutionCode                  <chr> "FMNH", "FMNH", "FMNH", "FMNH", "PUC-…
$ collectionCode                   <chr> "Fishes", "Fishes", "Fishes", "Fishes…
$ catalogNumber                    <chr> "54137", "54159", "54361", "54160", "…
$ recordNumber                     <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ identifiedBy                     <chr> "Dr. Carlos A. S. de Lucena : Pontifi…
$ dateIdentified                   <dttm> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, …
$ license                          <chr> "CC0_1_0", "CC0_1_0", "CC0_1_0", "CC0…
$ rightsHolder                     <chr> "The Field Museum of Natural History"…
$ recordedBy                       <chr> "J. D. Haseman", "J. D. Haseman", "J.…
$ typeStatus                       <chr> "Paratype", "Holotype", "Paratype", "…
$ establishmentMeans               <lgl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N…
$ lastInterpreted                  <dttm> 2025-02-06 22:09:00, 2025-02-06 22:0…
$ mediaType                        <chr> "StillImage", NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,…
$ issue                            <chr> "GEODETIC_DATUM_ASSUMED_WGS84;OCCURRE…


Now that we have the occurrence data, we can use rfs_update_occ_data() to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in the occurrence dataset. This function will run the previous workflow internally, but it will also include additional steps to obtain occurrence data automatically from GBIF.


Code
# Check the occurrence data against the reference species list
updated_occ_data <- rfs_update_occ_data(
    species_database = data_template_ref, 
    occurrence_df = occ_data
)


Let’s check the result of the rfs_update_occ_data() function:


Code
# Select only species column from GBIF and the ones that validated their status
summary_result <- updated_occ_data |>
    select(
        species_gbif,
        status_ref,
        valid_as_ref
    ) |>
    rename(
        species = species_gbif,
        status_gbif = status_ref,
        valid_species = valid_as_ref
    ) |>
    distinct() |>
    arrange(species)





Sample of the result of rfs_update_occ_data()

title: rFishStatus
text:
rFishStatus is a package designed to help you assess the status and nomenclature of fish species in input lists or occurrence datasets (currently only GBIF is supported). This tutorial will guide you through the process of using the package effectively.


To use the package, you need to prepare your data in a specific format following the rFishStatus template. To see an example of it you can run the following code:


Code
library(rFishStatus)
library(dplyr)

# Let's check the template reference
glimpse(data_template_ref)


Rows: 2,363
Columns: 15
$ scientific_name_complete    <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ scientific_name             <chr> "Geophagus abalios", "Limnochromis abeelei…
$ scientific_name_author      <chr> "López-Fernández  & Taphorn  2004", "Poll …
$ scientific_name_genus       <chr> "Geophagus", "Limnochromis", "Sparus", "He…
$ scientific_name_family      <chr> "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae", "Cichlidae", "Ci…
$ scientific_name_status      <chr> "Valid", "Synonym", "Uncertain", "Synonym"…
$ species_valid_name_complete <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ species_valid_as_complete   <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ species_valid_as_short      <chr> "Geophagus abalios", "Greenwoodochromis ab…
$ species_valid_name_genus    <chr> "Geophagus", "Greenwoodochromis", NA, "Aus…
$ species_valid_name_author   <chr> "López-Fernández & Taphorn 2004", "(Poll 1…
$ species_valid_name_year     <chr> "2004", "1949", NA, "1870", "2015", "1967"…
$ scientific_name_synonym_of  <chr> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA…
$ all_valid_species_complete  <chr> "Geophagus abalios López-Fernández & Tapho…
$ scientific_name_habitat     <chr> "freshwater", "freshwater", "freshwater", …


All functions in rFishStatuswill use this template as a reference. For more details please refer to the data template documentation.
This reference dataset will then be used to construct a reference list of fish species, which will be used to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in your input list. This is basically the List Curation Workflow shown in Design & Development section.



The first step in using rFishStatus is to create a reference species list from the data template. This list will be used to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in your input list. You can create the reference species list by running the following code:


Code
library(rFishStatus)

reference_spp_list <- rfs_get_species_list(
    # Here we use the data template reference
    # But you can use your own dataset
    df = data_template_ref
)

Once you obtain the reference list, you can load your input dataset to be assessed. This dataset should be a dataframe, with a column named species. For further details on the input dataset format, please refer to the rfs_update_list().


Let’s create a sample input list and compare it with the reference species list using rfs_update_list().


Code
# Create a sample input list
input_list <- data.frame(
    species = c(
        "Crenicichla britskii",
        "Cicha kelberi",
        "Geophagus brasiliensis"
    )
)

# Check the input list against the reference species list
result <- rfs_update_list(
    input_list = input_list,
    reference_list = reference_spp_list
)

A typo was added to the input list (Cicha kelberi) to demonstrate how rfs_update_list() can identify it.




The second workflow is the Occurrence Data Workflow, which is used to assess the status and nomenclature of fish species in occurrence datasets (so far this is specificaly tailored to work with GBIF data, so you will need GBIF credentials that can be obtained here). This workflow runs the previous workflow internally, but it also includes additional steps to obtain occurrence data automatically from GBIF. First you need to download the occurrence data from GBIF using rfs_download_occ_data(). This function will download the occurrence data automatically by interacting with the rgbif package. Let’s download all Crenicichla occurrence for the state of Paraná, Brazil, and save it in data/occ_data:


Code
# Download occurrence data from GBIF
# Obs. You don't need to assign the result to a variable, since it will execute and 
# save the data in the folder passed as an argument

dotenv::load_dot_env()

rfs_download_occ_data(
    gbif_user = Sys.getenv("GBIF_USER"),
    gbif_pwd = Sys.getenv("GBIF_PWD"),
    gbif_email = Sys.getenv("GBIF_EMAIL"),
    folder_name = "data/occ_data",
    country = "Brazil",
    state = "Paraná",
    reverse_polygon = TRUE,
    taxonkey = 2370916, # Taxonkey for Crenicichla
)


After downloading the data let’s check it in the folder data/occ_data:


Code
# Check the downloaded data
occ_data <- list.files("data/occ_data", full.names = TRUE) |>
    readr::read_delim()

dplyr::glimpse(occ_data)

Now that we have the occurrence data, we can use rfs_update_occ_data() to assess the status and nomenclature of the species in the occurrence dataset. This function will run the previous workflow internally, but it will also include additional steps to obtain occurrence data automatically from GBIF.


Code
# Check the occurrence data against the reference species list
updated_occ_data <- rfs_update_occ_data(
    species_database = data_template_ref, 
    occurrence_df = occ_data
)


Let’s check the result of the rfs_update_occ_data() function:


Code
# Select only species column from GBIF and the ones that validated their status
summary_result <- updated_occ_data |>
    select(
        species_gbif,
        status_ref,
        valid_as_ref
    ) |>
    rename(
        species = species_gbif,
        status_gbif = status_ref,
        valid_species = valid_as_ref
    ) |>
    distinct() |>
    arrange(species)
